metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: 0.5m WorldView-2DOM data production in Dayekou watershed on May, 2012
metadata.description: Trough the select tasking, we obtained the WorldView-2 stereo image data in Dayekou Watershed production in mid-May 2012. In the same year from July to August, 27 GPS ground control points (GCP) and checkpoints were measured based on the watershed differential GPS control network. Based on the full-field GCPs, the rational polynomial coefficients (RPC) files of WorldView-2 images were corrected in the digital photogrammetry software system. In the stereo model, 60 high-precision tie points evenly distributed were got through image matching technology, and the 1-m and 2-m resolution digital elevation model (DEM) were rapid extracted. Based on collinearity equations, images at nadir were corrected to adjust relief displacements and geometric errors, and the 0.5-m resolution digital orthorectified images DOM were obtained with the principle of digital differential rectification in Dayekou Basin.

background: The alpine region is important in riverine and watershed ecosystems as a contributor of freshwater, providing and stimulating specific habitats for biodiversity. In parallel, recent climate change, human activities, and other perturbations may disturb hydrological processes and eco-functions, creating the need for next-generation observational and modeling approaches to advance a predictive understanding of such processes in the alpine region. Water resources in the alpine region are headwaters that need to be regulated to sustain downstream ecosystems. However, perturbations induced by nature/climate change and human activities in recent years have significantly reformed hydrological processes and eco-functions. Accurate estimation and prediction of hydrological processes and their key impact factors has since become crucial.

Unfortunately, the scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research yet motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments. In comparison with the observations, using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation could improve the prediction of hydrological processes. However, due to the complexities of the earth system, there exist various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data (especially in the alpine region), which have to be validated and calibrated. In summary, to fill the knowledge gap and promote alpine region hydrology research, an integrated, distributed and multiscale observation dataset is essential and expected to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, allow the evaluation of distributed models and ultimately improve a predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions. In alpine hydrology, in addition to consistent hydrometeorological data obtained from distributed meteorological stations, snow cover and frozen ground are two important indexes and driving forces that manipulate hydrological processes. The maximum snow water equivalent (SWE) before ablation determines the storage of snowmelt – a major source of freshwater in the alpine region, while freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs) and soil moisture within the active layer alter water infiltration and, consequently, surface runoff and groundwater. To promote alpine hydrology research, the International Network for Alpine Research Catchment Hydrology (INARCH) was launched in 2015 by the Global Energy and Water Exchanges (GEWEX) project of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP), involving 18 catchments around the world. The INARCH has since connected individual observatories into an international network and data-share platform to lead frontier research on alpine region hydrometeorology and snow observation. Another community-based observation network, the Circumpolar Active Layer Monitoring (CALM) network, was initiated in the early 1990s to observe the response of the active layer and near-surface permafrost to climate change. The Heihe River Basin (HRB) is the second largest inland river basin in China and is known for its heterogeneous landscapes, diverse ecosystems, unique geographical characteristics and climate change over recent decades. As a major component of the ecohydrological processes in the arid/semi-arid HRB, the alpine hydrological processes, especially those related to snow cover and frozen ground in the upper reaches, have great impacts on runoff in the mountainous region, which then regulate agricultural development in the middle reaches and the ecosystems of the lower reaches.

In recent years, with climate warming, permafrost degradation has significantly affected runoff and the carbon cycle (Peng et al., 2016; Gao et al., 2018). Snow cover is widely distributed with unique characteristics in the study area. In the high-altitude mountainous region (elevation > 3800 m), influenced by the local microclimate and low temperature, snowfall could occur in any season. Temporary snow is the major snow cover type in the region at middle and low elevations because strong solar radiation and high air temperature lead to fast melting and sublimation of the snow. Drifting snow is also commonly observed in the region, which may lead to the redistribution of snowpack in high elevation regions (Essery et al., 1999; Li et al., 2014).

Blowing (drifting) snow is commonly observed in the Qilian mountain due to its high altitude and complex terrain. It is important to estimate the occurrence of blowing snow because it may cause redistributions of the snow cover and influence the sublimation of snow.

Soil heat conductivity is difficult to analyze because it is a function of soil density, soil moisture content (ice content in frozen ground), and soil temperature, which cannot be easily calculated using a simple formula. Therefore, site observations can be utilized to evaluate the parameterization of alpine hydrologic models.
research objective: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China.
This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years.

The associated open-access datasets include high-quality hydrometeorological data with specific respect to snow and frozen ground observations at the sub-basin and basin scales, which aims to address a variety of scientific questions including but not limited to: (1) how to provide accurate and effective forcing data for alpine hydrological models, (2) how to integrate observation, simulation and the acquired datasets for informative understanding, and (3) how perturbations (climate change and human activities) alter fundamental processes.
challenges: However, several formidable challenges, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, inhibit complete and consistent data collection where/when needed, which hinders the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models.

Unfortunately, the scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research yet motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments. However, the above modeling efforts suffered from 1) the availability of the forcing data (only two weather stations operated by the Chinese Meteorological Administration functioned in the upper reaches of the HRB) and 2) a lack of high-quality snow and frozen ground data for parameterization.
Unfortunately, this did not work well due to the influence of strong wind. Therefore, snow density data, which can be calculated using snow depth and SWE data, are not available at present.
methods: Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation.

Considering the characteristics of the study site, an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network has been established with seven automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and two superstations. At the basin scale, the observation aims to collect data for investigating the meteorological driving forces and for validation of the alpine hydrological models. At the sub-basin scale, small-scale observations and measurements focus on data such as precipitation, soil temperature and moisture, which are used to develop and improve hydrologic models, as well as to validate remote sensing products at medium to coarse resolutions (Jin et al., 2014). At the two superstations for snow cover and frozen ground observations, remote sensing products can be further validated using fine-resolution data. In total, seven AMSs, as well as the frozen ground and snow superstations (also incorporating meteorological observations), were established in the study area during the intensive observation period (IOP: 2013 -2014) to obtain the spatially distributed meteorological variables. After the IOP, four typical AMSs were selected and retained for continuous observation, which is expected to provide long-term datasets. The observed meteorological variables include wind (speed and direction), air temperature, humidity, infrared temperature, air pressure, four-component radiation, and precipitation. Accumulation and depletion processes were measured automatically at the Yakou snow superstation. The observed components included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE, measured by GammaMONitor, GMON), albedo of the snow surface and blowing (drifting) snow flux (measured by FlowCapt). Soil temperature and moisture were measured within six layers at each AMS, while evapotranspiration (ET) was observed by eddy covariance (EC) at three AMSs located in permafrost, seasonally frozen ground and a transient zone to observe freeze-thaw (FT) processes. At the sub-basin scale, a wireless sensor network (WSN) with 40 nodes was established to capture seasonal changes in soil temperature and moisture. At the A’rou frozen ground superstation, soil temperature and moisture profiles were intensively measured in eighteen layers to a depth of 3.2 m (in a nested pattern with more layers in the topsoil) to obtain the soil hydrothermal features under freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs). In addition, thermal conductivity and hydraulic conductivity in the topsoil were also measured to observe the dynamic hydrothermal processes within.

Snow depth was measured by SR50A (Campbell, USA), which determines the distance between the sensor and the target by sending out ultrasonic pulses and listening for the returning echoes reflected from the target. Snow water equivalent (SWE) was measured by GMON (CS725 GammaMONitor, Campbell, USA) from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 at a temporal resolution of 6 hr. FlowCapt (IAV, Switzerland) was used to measure the number of blowing snow grains at 3 heights (0-1 m, 1-2 m, and 2-3 m) every 10 mins.
dataset: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China. Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation. The updated datasets were released to scientists with multidisciplinary backgrounds (i.e., cryosphere science, hydrology, and meteorology), and they are expected to serve as a testing platform to provide accurate forcing data and validate and evaluate remote sensing products and hydrological models for a broader community.

This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years. Composed of seven standard hydrometeorological stations, one snow superstation and one frozen ground superstation, the observation network serves as an integrated research platform aiming to provide prominent datasets (e.g., hydrometeorology, snow, and frozen ground) of the hydrometeorological processes in the upper reaches of the HRB, which is expected to support alpine region hydrological model development and simulations along with remote sensing observation.

A comprehensive snow dataset from the Yakou snow superstation has been updated since the summer of 2013. The observed snow variables included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE) and blowing (drifting) snow. Data obtained from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 are summarized in Figure 4, with additional plots for precipitation, ET, soil temperature and moisture. The datasets are available from 2012/12/05 to 2017/12/31, with intermittent loss mostly due to power loss and sensor malfunctions at high altitudes.

In this paper, a suite of alpine hydrology datasets observed from an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) is presented.

background: Since its first introduction in 1958, Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) have become an important foundational data source for various geological analyses, simulations, and calculations in GIS spatial databases. They have been widely applied in fields such as surveying, civil engineering, geology, mining engineering, landscape design, road design, agricultural water conservancy construction, flood prevention and disaster reduction, battlefield simulation, hydrological analysis, climate change research, and disaster monitoring. However, on one hand, the production of DEM data in China is slow, and many areas, especially mountainous regions, lack high-precision DEMs; on the other hand, the nationwide 25m high-precision DEM data is classified and generally difficult to obtain, severely restricting the development of scientific research in fields such as geology. Therefore, the rapid extraction of high-precision DEMs using satellite stereo imagery is a basic research area of significant practical value. In recent years, research institutions such as the Qilian Mountain Forest Ecology Station of the State Forestry Administration, the Gansu Provincial Water Conservation Forest Research Institute, the Cold and Arid Regions Environmental and Engineering Research Institute of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and Beijing Normal University have conducted multiple field surveys and scientific research on forest hydrology and land surface ecology in the upper Heihe River Basin, particularly in the Dayekouzi Basin.
research objective: This study uses the digital photogrammetry software Leica LPS (Leica Photogrammetry Suite) to prepare a 2.5m grid size DEM data at a scale of 1:5,000 based on WorldView-2 stereo imagery for the Danye Kou watershed.
challenges: Due to the complex terrain and inconvenient transportation in the southern part of the study area, there are no ground control points covered. Since the RPC model is not a strict orbital model and many parameters lack physical significance, establishing a ground model solely relying on the RPC file in the absence of ground control points leads to systematic errors. Additionally, factors such as fragmented terrain and uneven distribution of tie points in the study area result in some automatically matched points not accurately aligning with the surface model, leading to "outlier points" or "drilling points."
methods: Based on ground control points from the entire field, the RPC files of WorldView-2 imagery were corrected. Using a digital photogrammetry software system, a digital elevation model (DEM) at a scale of 1:5,000 for the upper Dayekouzi watershed in the Heihe River basin was quickly extracted through automatic image matching technology on the stereo model. An initial three-dimensional surface model was established using the RPC files of WorldView-2 imagery, and geodetic GPS tie points and check points were accurately marked in both left and right images one by one. Through image matching, the regional DEM was automatically extracted. In the overlapping area of the stereo image pair, 80 evenly distributed image tie points were automatically generated, and after checking each pair of corresponding points and removing outliers, 60 high-precision tie points were retained. Aerial triangulation was performed, and the overall accuracy of the results was within 0.5 pixels.
dataset: The data sources used for preparing DEM data mainly include four categories: (1) WorldView-2 stereo image pairs and RPB (equivalent to RPC) files. The stereo image pair data for the study area was acquired on May 16, 2012, with a resolution of 0.5m (customized only for the Chinese region) using the WGS84 geographic coordinate system. (2) National geodetic control point results. The plane reference for the results control points is CGCS2000, and the elevation reference is the 56 Yellow Sea elevation system. (3) Field GPS control point measurements. Five control points were added within the survey area. (4) Contour line data at a scale of 1:100,000 for the Dayekou watershed and the 2004 remote sensing experimental dataset QuickBird multi-spectral remote sensing image products, used for DEM quality verification.
findings: The results indicate that the maximum elevation error between the two groups is 1.9m, meeting the requirement of a scale mountain class I accuracy of 2.5m.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of collecting hydrometeorological data in alpine regions compare to those encountered in creating high-resolution DEMs using satellite stereo pairs?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges of collecting hydrometeorological data in alpine regions include cold and harsh climates, high altitudes, and complex topography, which inhibit consistent data collection and development of models. In contrast, creating high-resolution DEMs using satellite stereo pairs faces challenges due to complex terrain, lack of ground control points, and potential systematic errors in the RPC model, leading to inaccuracies such as 'fly points' or 'drilling points'.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the scarcity of observation data in alpine regions, and how do these factors impact the development of hydrological models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The scarcity of observation data in alpine regions is primarily due to difficulties in access and technological barriers, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography. These factors hinder complete and consistent data collection, limiting the availability of forcing data and high-quality snow and frozen ground data needed for parameterizing hydrological models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the use of remote sensing data combined with data assimilation considered beneficial for improving the prediction of hydrological processes in alpine regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Remote sensing data combined with data assimilation can improve the prediction of hydrological processes because it helps fill the data gaps caused by the scarcity of direct observations in alpine regions. This approach can provide more comprehensive coverage and allow for validation and calibration, despite the inherent uncertainties in remote sensing data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes difficulties in accurately extracting digital elevation models (DEM) using satellite stereo pair methods in regions with complex terrain?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: In regions with complex terrain, challenges in extracting accurate digital elevation models (DEM) using satellite stereo pair methods arise due to uneven distribution of ground control points, system errors in RPC models, and the occurrence of 'flying' or 'drilling' points caused by inaccurate automatic matching of the terrain model. Additionally, the absence of ground control points in some areas exacerbates these difficulties.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) for data collection in alpine regions with challenging climates and terrains?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) in challenging alpine regions can lead to the collection of gap-free meteorological and hydrological data, enabling the monitoring of snow accumulation and ablation processes. However, it may also face challenges such as power loss and sensor malfunctions, especially at high altitudes, resulting in intermittent data loss. This can hinder the accuracy and consistency of datasets necessary for hydrological modeling and remote sensing validation.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop high-resolution DEMs using satellite stereo image pairs in regions with complex topography?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing high-resolution DEMs using satellite stereo image pairs is important because it addresses the scarcity of high-precision DEMs in regions with complex topography, which are crucial for various geoscientific analyses, simulations, and calculations in fields like hydrology, climate change research, and disaster monitoring.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of using automatic meteorological stations and superstations to collect hydrometeorological data in the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives include capturing spatially distributed meteorological variables to investigate meteorological driving forces, validate alpine hydrological models, and support long-term data collection for understanding watershed science and functions in the region, especially in relation to snow and frozen ground processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network be effectively established to monitor hydrometeorological, snow, and frozen ground data in alpine regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: An integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network can be effectively established by deploying a series of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and superstations for snow and frozen ground observations. This involves continuous monitoring of meteorological variables, capturing snow accumulation and ablation processes, and measuring soil temperature and moisture at various depths and locations. The network should focus on both basin and sub-basin scales to collect comprehensive datasets for model validation and improvement.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the creation of high-resolution digital elevation models (DEMs) in remote and complex terrains?
Enablement.Answer: The use of WorldView-2 stereo imagery and digital photogrammetry software like Leica Photogrammetry Suite (LPS) has enabled the rapid extraction of high-resolution DEMs in complex terrains. By utilizing the imagery's RPC files and GPS ground control points, researchers can correct and generate precise 3D surface models, even in remote areas with limited ground control.

Enablement.Question: How does integrating remote sensing data with ground-based observations enhance the predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes?
Enablement.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data with ground-based observations, such as those obtained from automatic meteorological stations and snow/frozen ground superstations, allows for the validation and calibration of remote sensing products. This combined approach provides accurate forcing data for hydrological models, improving the prediction of hydrological processes and understanding the effects of snow cover and freeze-thaw cycles in alpine regions.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are faced in collecting consistent and complete hydrometeorological data in high-altitude alpine regions, and how are these addressed?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges in collecting consistent data in alpine regions include harsh climate conditions, high altitudes, and complex topography. These are addressed by establishing integrated observation networks with automatic meteorological stations and superstations that monitor various meteorological variables, snow properties, and soil conditions, thereby ensuring comprehensive data collection despite environmental difficulties.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might researchers face when attempting to achieve gap-free data collection in alpine hydrology, and why are these challenges significant?
Expectation.Answer: Several formidable challenges, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, inhibit complete and consistent data collection in alpine hydrology. These challenges hinder the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models due to difficulties of access and technological barriers, which results in a scarcity of observation data and affects the parameterization of hydrological models.

Expectation.Question: Why might automatic image matching techniques lead to inaccuracies in DEM extraction, and what factors contribute to these errors?
Expectation.Answer: Automatic image matching techniques might lead to inaccuracies in DEM extraction due to complex terrain and uneven distribution of ground control points. Factors such as fragmented terrain and the presence of 'fly points' or 'drilling points' can result in some automatic matching points not accurately aligning with the surface model, leading to system errors when relying solely on RPC files without ground control points.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated benefits of using an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network for alpine hydrology research, and why are these benefits crucial?
Expectation.Answer: The anticipated benefits of using an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network for alpine hydrology research include providing accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validating remote sensing data, and evaluating distributed models. These benefits are crucial for improving the predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions, especially in the context of climate change and human-induced perturbations.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations of using remote sensing data for alpine hydrological modeling, given the uncertainties and complexities of the earth system?
Judgmental.Answer: Remote sensing data for alpine hydrological modeling can be limited by uncertainties inherent in the data due to the complexities of the earth system, especially in alpine regions. These uncertainties require validation and calibration to ensure accuracy. The scarcity of observation data, technological barriers, and the effects of climate change further complicate the use of remote sensing data in this context.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection in remote alpine regions can overcome technological and environmental barriers to ensure reliability.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection in remote alpine regions uses an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network, including automatic meteorological stations and superstations for snow and frozen ground. This setup, despite challenges like harsh climates and complex topographies, allows comprehensive data gathering critical for hydrological modeling and remote sensing validation.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how digital elevation models (DEM) are accurately generated in areas with complex terrain and limited ground control points.
Assertion.Answer: Digital elevation models are generated using WorldView-2 stereo imagery and the RPC model. The process involves GPS ground control points to improve accuracy, automatic image matching for DEM extraction, and aerial triangulation to ensure precision, even with challenging terrain and limited control points.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets from different sensors and observation networks are integrated to study alpine hydrological processes effectively.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets from various sensors and observation networks are integrated using a combination of automatic meteorological stations, snow superstations, and frozen ground superstations. This integration captures comprehensive meteorological, snow, and soil data, facilitating the study of hydrological processes and allowing for the validation of remote sensing products.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used to capture hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data in alpine regions and discuss their integration into a multiscale observation network.
Request/Directive.Answer: Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). Snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using advanced techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were obtained to capture freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation. The integrated, distributed, and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network includes seven AMSs and two superstations. This network aims to collect data for investigating meteorological driving forces and validating alpine hydrological models, integrating observations with simulations to enhance understanding of alpine hydrological processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential methods for expanding data coverage and improving data quality in alpine hydrology research, considering technological and environmental constraints.
Request/Directive.Answer: To expand data coverage and improve data quality in alpine hydrology research, an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network has been established with automatic meteorological stations and superstations for snow and frozen ground observations. The network addresses constraints by measuring variables such as wind, temperature, humidity, radiation, and precipitation, and capturing snow and freeze-thaw processes. The use of wireless sensor networks and the validation of remote sensing products with fine-resolution data at superstations further enhance data quality. Continued observation and dataset updates aim to provide accurate forcing data, validate remote sensing products, and support hydrological model development.
